description:
Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae serovar 5b str. L20 is a Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic, coccobacillus bacterium that belongs to the genus Actinobacillus. It is a causative agent of porcine pleuropneumonia, a severe and often fatal respiratory disease in swine.

This particular strain, L20, is classified as serovar 5b, which refers to the specific antigenic properties of its cell surface. Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae has been divided into 18 different serovars based on these antigenic variations.

The L20 strain was isolated from a case of porcine pleuropneumonia and has been used extensively in research to understand the pathogenesis, epidemiology, and host-pathogen interactions of this important swine pathogen. It is known to possess various virulence factors, such as capsular polysaccharides, lipopolysaccharides, and exotoxins, which contribute to its ability to cause severe lung damage and disease in infected pigs.

Understanding the biology and characteristics of Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae serovar 5b str. L20 is crucial for developing effective prevention and control strategies against porcine pleuropneumonia, which continues to be a significant economic burden for the swine industry worldwide.
